results.title: Coral kingdom
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Noel Monkman
results.brief_description: The fish and corals of the Great Barrier Reef. Photographed underwater, the film shows many different shell fish and corals; box fish, king schnapper, seaworm, jellyfish, anemones and other sea creatures.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Noel Monkman

results.title: Coral jungle
results.creator_credit: Jacques-Yves Cousteau, Wolper Productions and Jacques Cousteau Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
The coral reef with its myriad of little homes, caves and crevices is an attractive centre for tropical marine life. A delicate balance is maintained by all its inhabitants, for life on the reef is a continuous struggle to survive. Jacques Cousteau and the crew of Calypso are shown examining the different varieties of plants and animals in the reefs. Commentator: Rod Serling.

results.title: Cops, spies and private eyes
results.brief_description: Australia’s first television policeman, Terry McDermott, better known as Detective Sergeant Frank Bronson from “Homicide” narrates this documentary on the Australian cop shows which screened on commercial television from 1956-2000. Features footage from both popular long-running and short-lived series. Television shows include: Al Munch (I Found Joe Barton) ; Consider Your Verdict ; Homicide ; Hunter ; Divorce Court ; The Unloved ; Division Four ; The Linkmen ; The Long Arm ; Matlock Police ; Boney ; The Spoiler ; Vendetta ; Ryan ; Silent Number ; Shannon’s Mob ; King’s Men ; Bluey ; Case for the Defence ; Cop Shop ; Bellamy ; Waterloo Station ; Special Squad ; Rafferty’s Rules ; Skirts ; Bony ; The Feds ; Blue Heelers ; Singapore Sling ; Cody ; Halifax FP ; Water Rats ; State Coroner ; Good Guys Bad Guys ; Murder Call ; Stingers and Above the Law.

results.title: Copping Music
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Copper sheet roofing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plumbing”.
Softening of copper sheet by annealing; principle and method of joining sheets together by welting; single and double welts. Application to actual roofing: use of seaming pliers; making the upstand at wall end; fixing of sheets to roofboards with tacks or cleats; standing seams. Treatment at roof edge: cover piece and flashing at upstand end; another type of upstand to fit a corner in which there is an arris; use of pleating tool; the batten roll, joint, upstand and roll end.

results.title: Copper plumbing
results.creator_credit: Cine Service Productions and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: The development and use of prefabricated copper plumbing in Australia. The advantages of seamless copper tubing, enabling workshop assembly of plumbing units; how copper plumbing can be concealed in walls; how architect, builder and plumber can plan ahead together; how these techniques have been used in a number of Australian public buildings, offices, blocks of flats, and small homes.
results.description: The development and use of prefabricated copper plumbing in Australia. results.title: Copper pipe bending
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plumbing”.
Shows various methods of copper pipe bending in use. The steel spring; lead loading; machine bending; sand loading; use of compressors or rams; consolidation of sand; marking into pulls, heating, pulling and dressing.

results.title: Copper kaleidoscope
results.creator_credit: Heinrich Fueter, Condor Films and Herbert E. Meyer
results.brief_description: The seemingly unlimited use of copper and copper alloys through five thousand years of history has established this metal as one of the most valuable possessions for the human population. The film shows the digging of the ore, smelting, ingots, rolling, shaping, polishing and finally the many things made from copper today.

results.title: Copper from Peko
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: A survey of the copper mine at Peko, seven miles east of Tennant Creek in the Northern Terriitory. The mine is the fourth largest in the Commonwealth and produces ore containing 8.1/4% copper. The mine, still in various stages of development, is shown, and the various processes in preparing the ore for shipment to Port Kembla, via Alice Springs, are illustrated. With potential resources of lead and zinc, the Peko mine is further evidence of the mineral wealth of Australia’s Northern Territory.
